comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: I love the platform built from sleepers. I thought it might be a fire risk in the steam train age

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Located on the now 'semi-abandoned' loop line between Picton and Mittagong in the Southern Highlands of New South Wales. The line now sees very little traffic. Sadly washaways and a freeway have blocked the line to through traffic. The NSW Rail Transport Museum run heritage trains between Picton and Buxton at the northern end of the loop.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: There is actually a tunnel for the train under the freeway.   Several bridges have fallen down.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009]  Hi Mich, are you sure the Loop line doesn't mostly remain west of the freeway (except for the twin bridges at Aylmerton?)  I'd love to do the complete walk one day from Mittagong to Picton then catch the main line back. Not sure How easy such a long walk will be on railway sleepers though.
When taking a look on Google Earth it seems to be a far better and shorter route than the main line which has to do several circular arcs near Yerrinbool and two deep tunnels just to ascend Catherine Hill to Alpine

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It would be tiring to walk on sleepers - zzzzzzz-ZZZ-zzzzzz -

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Maybe I will build a billycart with flanged wheels 1432mm apart then?

comment.author: 49705600@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Well, it certainly didn't survive a bush fire in the 1970s. Note the platform is on the Up side in this photo. The new platform, constructed in 1994 by the NSWRTM & Picton Rotary, is on the Down (main line) side.

comment.author: 42834825@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I have walked it between Hill Top and Mittagong, and significant chunks between Hill Top and Thirlmere. There are numerous bridges missing (burnt or otherwise destroyed), but the gullies are passable on foot unless the creeks are up. If you do this route, you will want to join the line near the Bradken Plant at Willow Vale and depart it at Thirlmere, or else you will end up walking on the main southern line when it intersects with the Loop Line.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tah727] Thanks for the info Travis, I'd like to walk it sometime. Can you elaborate where it intersects with the main line (other than near the Picton Tunnel further on)?

comment.author: 49705600@N06
comment._content: Right next to the old Hume Highway at the northern end of Mittagong.
